snippet: A new law is intended to save energy in New York City by forbidding shops and restaurants to lure customers on sweltering days with blasts of cold air out on the sidewalk.
abstract: New York City Council passes law barring almost all shops and restaurants in city from running air-conditioners while doors and windows are open, common tactic to lure potential customers from street on hot days; move expands previous rule, which only applied to large chain stores, and does include some exceptions for outdoor cafes and food counters; Mayor Bill de Blasio praises law before signing it, calling it one more step in city's efforts to conserve energy and fight global warming.
lead_paragraph: A new law is intended to save energy in New York City by forbidding shops and restaurants to lure customers on sweltering days with blasts of cold air out on the sidewalk.

headline.main: Stores Must Keep Doors Closed if Air-Conditioning Is On
headline.print_headline: Most Stores in City Will Have to Close Doors and Windows if Air-Conditioning Is On
